courses.title: Europe Since the Renaissance
courses.description: Social, political, economic, and cultural history of Europe since the Renaissance.  Topics include Renaissance; Reformation; political, scientific, and industrial revolutions; nationalism; fascism and communism; decolonization.

courses.title: Engineering in History
courses.description: Uses historical case studies to examine the relationship between engineers and the larger society in which they function.  Often taught jointly with engineering faculty.

courses.title: Early American History
courses.description: North America to 1763, including native cultures, contacts with European colonizers, settlement strategies and patterns, and foundation of American political and economic institutions.

courses.title: The American Revolution and Constitution
courses.description: The American Revolution as political debate, war, and social upheaval, with attention to the framing and ratification of the Constitution.

courses.title: History of the Old South to 1865
courses.description: A study of social, political, and economic developments in the South from the colonial period through the Civil War.

courses.title: History of the New South since 1865
courses.description: An examination of social, political, and economic developments from the Reconstruction period to the present.

courses.title: Modern America: World War II and After
courses.description: Dawning of the atomic age, anticommunism, the Civil Rights Movement, New Frontier and Great Society, Vietnam and the tumultuous 1960s, and end of Cold War.

courses.title: History of Sports in America
courses.description: Examines American sport from colonial to contemporary times. Focuses on the rise of organized sports and the influence of race, class, gender, and ethnicity.

courses.title: Social Issues and Public Policy
courses.description: Draws on sociological theory and research to understand the major economic, social, and cultural issues facing American society today.

courses.title: Environmental Sociology
courses.description: This course examines theories about how human society impacts the natural world through economic, political, and social systems.

courses.title: Food and Society
courses.description: Survey of the complex social web of identity, culture, politics, economics, history, and power behind food systems in the U.S. and globally.

courses.title: Revolutionary Europe: 1789-1914
courses.description: Industrialization and political revolution, the development of political ideologies and labor activism, modern nation-state building, and imperialism from the French Revolution to World War I.

courses.title: Twentieth Century Europe: 1914 to Present
courses.description: Global war and the Bolshevik Revolution, rise and fall of Mussolini and Hitler, Stalinism, the Holocaust, Cold War, decolonization, and the movement toward European integration.

courses.title: History of Islamic Societies
courses.description: Survey of Middle East from pre-Islamic times to Ottoman rule, tracing the development of Islamic society and emphasizing the plurality of culture in the region.

courses.title: History of the Modern Middle East
courses.description: The transformation of the Middle East in the modern era and the relationship of the "East" and "West" in the contemporary world.

courses.title: Colonial Latin America and the World
courses.description: An exploration of colonial Latin America from the perspective of Global History.

courses.title: North American Borderlands
courses.description: Introduction to the history of early Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, Texas, New Mexico, Arizona and California in the Spanish Colonial period.

courses.title: Modern Latin American History
courses.description: Introduces students to the socioeconomic, political, cultural, and environmental conditions that have shaped life in Latin America from the 1800s to the present.

courses.title: Traditional Asia and Its Legacy
courses.description: Civilizations of East Asia up to 1850, emphasizing traditional cultures in China and Japan, including religion, science, formation of empires, social life, and commerce.

courses.title: Asia in the Modern World
courses.description: Civilizations of India, China, and Japan since 1600, emphasizing Western impact and adaptation of these countries' political, economic, and social systems.

courses.title: Introduction to the History of Disease and Medicine
courses.description: Introduction to the history of disease and medicine since the Renaissance focusing on infectious diseases, the rise of germ theory, and evolution of medical training.  Cerdit not allowed for both HTS 2080 and HTS 3087.

courses.title: The Scientific Revolution
courses.description: A critical approach to the Scientific Revolution, introducing students to primary documents and images from the period and emphasizing interpretive strategies and methods.

courses.title: Technology and Science in the Industrial Age
courses.description: Surveys major developments in technology and science since 1600 and places them in the broader social context of their times.

courses.title: Technology and Society
courses.description: Analyzes social conditions that promote or retard technological activity, emphasizing role of business, the state, and scientific and engineering professions, and the emergence of consumerism.

courses.title: Reel History I: US History through Hollywood Films
courses.description: Students evaluate films as sources for specific historical events by viewing films, reading historical documents, and applying critical analysis to written assignments and class discussions.

courses.title: Semester in the City: Engaging Communities
courses.description: Explores how urban neighborhoods work focusing on Westside neighborhoods from a variety of perspectives. Students will work with residents in designing a sustainability project.

courses.title: Sci, Tech & Modern World
courses.description: An introduction to perspectives on how developments in science and technology at once reflect and influence politics and society on a global scale.

courses.title: Historical and Social Research
courses.description: Interdisciplinary survey based on critical readings of the methods historians and social scientists use to generate knowledge about social life.  Students engage in "hands-on" research.

courses.title: HTS Internship - Paid
courses.description: Undergraduate internship for which the student is paid and receives audit credit. Freshmen and sophomores only.

courses.title: HTS Internship-Credit
courses.description: Unpaid undergraduate internship for which the student receives pass/fail credit. Freshmen and sophomores only.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research Assistantship
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Allows a group of students and a professor to study topics not covered in other courses in the department.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Allows a group of students and a professor to study topics not covered in other courses in the department.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Allows a group of students and a professor to study topics not covered in other courses in the department.

courses.title: History of American Business
courses.description: Evolution of business institutions from colonial period to present, including entrepreneurship, business-government relations, institutional innovation, and twentieth century managerial capitalism.

courses.title: Sociology of Economic Institutions
courses.description: Examines links between economic structures-markets, regulatory bodies, and labor relations systems-and the wider structural and cultural context.

courses.title: American Environmental History
courses.description: Transformation of the North American environment since 1500, including different notions of nature, romantic responses to wilderness during industrialization, rise of conservation movements, and environmental policy.

courses.title: United States Labor History
courses.description: The changing nature of work and labor relations, with focus on unionization and government regulation, and equity issues in the workplace.

courses.title: Sociology of Work, Industry, and Occupations
courses.description: Analyzes paid employment as a decisive social attachment, emphasizing work organizations, technological change and authority relations, and social inequality among diverse groups of employees.

courses.title: Class, Power, and Social Inequality
courses.description: This course examines how social class and the market economy affect inequality and stratification in the U.S., with additional attention to the roles of race and gender.

courses.title: The American Civil War
courses.description: Social, economic, political, and military aspects of the Civil War, including causes of the war, military campaigns, and long-term consequences.

courses.title: Organizing for Social Change
courses.description: Students will explore how people organize to amplify their voices, build power, and enact change. They will apply theory and organizing skills to advance change on campus.

courses.title: The City in American History
courses.description: Examines the historical background of the American city since colonial times, including city planning, urban technology and services, neighborhoods, and race relations.

courses.title: Urban Sociology
courses.description: Sociological perspectives on the city, urbanization, and problems of community, evolution of cities and problems of urban life in the United States and Third World.

courses.title: History of the Vietnam War
courses.description: Diplomatic, military, and social aspects of America's war in Vietnam, including antiwar protests, the defense industry boom, and the war's enduring impact on American life.

courses.title: Women and Gender in the United States
courses.description: Course examines themes and theories of women's and gender history since the colonial period, including work, family, race, sexuality, and politics.

courses.title: Sociology of Gender
courses.description: Gender as a dimension of social life that shapes and is shaped by the economy, schooling, family, politics, medicine and health, race, and social class.

courses.title: New Religions and Cults in America
courses.description: Explores controversial and influential new religious movements and cults in America, focusing on their origin, appeal, and impact.

courses.title: The Family, Sexuality, and Social Change in America
courses.description: Changing patterns of family life and sex roles since colonial times, with a focus on mainstream ideals, utopian alternatives, and social criticism.

courses.title: Gender and Technology
courses.description: Course examines the ways in which the design, development, and application of technologies, as well as cultural responses to them, have been gendered historically.

courses.title: Women in Science and Engineering
courses.description: Women in science and engineering and gender differences in participation, location, and status.  Examines education, access, and apprenticeship, culture of science and engineering.

courses.title: Gender and Sports
courses.description: Examines how gender norms and beliefs shape sport structures, participation opportunities and experiences in American sport.

courses.title: Slaves without Masters: Free People of Color before 1865
courses.description: Free people of color during the era of slavery, including everyday life, political and social philosophies, literature, community development, and movements for social change.

courses.title: African American History to 1865
courses.description: The experience of African and African American people in North America from the beginnings of slavery until the era of emancipation in the Civil War.

courses.title: African American History since 1865
courses.description: The African American experience since 1865, including Reconstruction, segregation, the African American family, the Harlem Renaissance, the Civil Rights Movement, and Black Power.

courses.title: Sociology of Race and Ethnicity
courses.description: Nature and significance of dominant/minority relations, including legacies of colonialism and slavery, roots of residential segregation, and effects of race on American politics.

courses.title: The Civil Rights Movement
courses.description: Examines why the civil rights movement emerged, how it was successful, and the impact it had on the U.S.

courses.title: Ancient Greece: Gods, Heroes, and RuinS
courses.description: Classical Athens and Sparta, myths and legends in historical context. Course ends with Alexander the Great and the rise of Rome.

courses.title: Ancient Rome: From Greatness to Ruins
courses.description: Growth of the Republic, antics and follies of the emperors, accomplishments of Rome, and causes of decline. Early Christianity and its impact on Europe included.

courses.title: Medieval Europe: 350 to 1400
courses.description: The rise of barbarian kingdoms from Rome's ashes, the explosion of  Islam, the monastic movement, Charlemagne's empire, the blossoming of medieval culture, and developinG European monarchies.

courses.title: European Labor History
courses.description: The labor movement from 1700s to the present, including an examination of Marx and socialism, unionization, and work conditions, especially in Britain, Germany, and France.

courses.title: Modern European Intellectual History
courses.description: Introduction to intellectual problems and trends in modern Europe, including loss of faith in progress, evil and ethics, post-colonialism, feminism, linguistics, and psycho-analytic thought.

courses.title: Medieval England
courses.description: Political, economic, and cultural development of England during the Middle Ages (c. 350-1400). Myths and legends of Stonehenge, the Druids, and King Arthur's Camelot explored.

courses.title: Britain from 1815-1914
courses.description: Developments in nineteenth-century Britain, including the industrial revolution, the growth of political democracy, imperialism, and movements for Irish Home rule and democratic socialism.

courses.title: Britain Since 1914
courses.description: Britain's experience of two world wars, the growth of Labour and decline of the Liberals, the Welfare State, Thatcherism, and Tony Blair's "New Labour".

courses.title: The French Revolution
courses.description: Economic, intellectual, and cultural causes of the French Revolution, Jacobinism and the Terror, careers of Robespierre and Danton, and rise and fall of Napoleon's empire.

courses.title: Modern France
courses.description: France from 1815 to 1968, emphasizing the continuing project of creating France as a powerful nation within the context of global culture and politics.

courses.title: Modern Spain
courses.description: Resistance to Napoleon, deformed industrialization, Anarchist and fascist experiments form the background for Spain's transition from dictatorship to democracy after Franco's death.

courses.title: Science, Politics, and Culture in Nazi Germany
courses.description: Examines the social, political and cultural context of science and technology in Nazi Germany to understand the interaction of science and politics under totalitarian regimes.

courses.title: Modern Russian History and Society
courses.description: Provides an overview of Russian history during the 20th Century.  Special emphasis will be on the Soviet period of Russian history from 1917-1991.

courses.title: Women and the Politics of Gender in the Middle East
courses.description: The role of women in imperial, nationalist, and Islamist political programs in the Middle East and the impact of politics on women's lives.

courses.title: Globalization in the Modern Era
courses.description: This course examines the process of globalization and global change in the twentieth century.  Also offers a critical examination of various theories of globalization.

courses.title: Modern China
courses.description: The decline of Confucian order, the impact of the West, changes and continuities of Chinese culture, the Communist revolution, nationalism, and economic reforms since 1978.

courses.title: Modern Japan
courses.description: Japan's transformation in one century from a feudal state into an economic superpower and the impact of these changes on the Japanese people.

courses.title: Sociology of Development
courses.description: Course examines competing perspectives on international development and surveys some of the crucial issues, including political instability, facing the Third World today.

courses.title: History of Global Societies
courses.description: Examines the historical patterns of interaction and inter- dependence between world regions, from approximately the 13th century to global interdependence to the contemporary world.

courses.title: Sociology of Politics and Society
courses.description: Political sociology studies the way power is distributed in society. This course takes a comparative and historical approach, focusing on the development of the nation-state.

courses.title: Revolutionary Movements in the Modern World
courses.description: Comparative analysis of the origin, development, and impact of major twentieth century revolutionary movements.

courses.title: Social Movements
courses.description: Why do social movements emerge? Why might they succeed? This course examines how ordinary people challenge powerful segments of society and contribute to social change.

courses.title: Culture and Society
courses.description: Covers core issues in the study of culture. Focuses on key sites, social practices, and institutions. Topics include education, medicine, consumption, and the mass media.

courses.title: Sociology of Crime
courses.description: This course examines the theories and issues such as perceptions of crime and criminals, characteristics of offenders and victims, and how crime is studied.

courses.title: Sociology of Education
courses.description: Examines sociological perspectives on how individual, school, and social factors influence students and teachers. Particular attention is paid to gender, race, ethnicity, and social class.

courses.title: Sociology of Sports
courses.description: Examines what constitutes "sports," and uses sociological lens to study sports relationship to education, policy, media, deviance, violence as well as gender, race and class.

courses.title: Foundations of Sports Studies
courses.description: Offers case studies of the multidisciplinary study of sports using the lenses of history, sociology, economics, science and technology to understand sports practices and controversies.

courses.title: History of Intelligence and National Security
courses.description: Examines the Cold War’s most important spy cases and operations to better understand the interplay between the world of secrets and intelligence and the world of statecraft and technology.

courses.title: History of Rocketry
courses.description: Examines the history of rocketry, scientists, and organizations in the US, USSR, and Europe during the twentieth century.

courses.title: Technology and the Environment
courses.description: Examines how technology affected the environment during the 20th Century, with special attention to issues like industrialization, pollution, overcrowding, and the biotech revolution.

courses.title: Sociology of Science
courses.description: The growth of science, its social structure; deviance and norms, the social context of scientific knowledge and practice, and science policy.  Credit not allowed for both HTS 3082 and HTS 6115.

courses.title: Culture and Technology
courses.description: Modernism and post-modernism: this course investigates culturally creative responses to modern manufacturing, transportation (trains, cars, airplanes), evolving gender ideals, and new communications.

courses.title: Sociology of Medicine and Health
courses.description: Relationship between health and society, including health care problems in the United States and culture's role in defining health and sickness and in determining appropriate therapies.

courses.title: History of Medicine
courses.description: An introduction to historical perspectives on the development of medicine, and its relationship to health, illness, and society.  Credit not allowed for both HTS 3087 and HTS 2080.

courses.title: Race, Medicine & Science
courses.description: Examines how race is an issue in medicine and science in ways such as education, professions, treatments, experiments, and as a subject of analysis.

courses.title: Science, Technology and Sports
courses.description: This course examines what constitutes a "sport," debates on the role of social inequality in sports, and the intersection of science, technology and sport.

courses.title: Introduction to Museum Studies
courses.description: Covers theoretical and practical issues in museum studies, including the role of material culture in scholarly work, registration of artifacts, exhibit design, and public relations.

courses.title: Social Theory and Social Structure
courses.description: Introduction to social theory, providing students with skills for reading theory and examining works of major social theorists, including Marx, Weber, Durkheim, Gilman, and Bourdieu.

courses.title: Honor's Thesis
courses.description: This course is designed to allow honor's students to distinguish themselves by producing a significant, original research paper.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special Topics in HTS.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Allows a group of students and a professor to  study topics not covered in other courses in the department.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Allows a group of students and a professor to study topics not covered in other courses in the department.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Allows a group of students and a professor to study topics not covered in other courses in the department.

courses.title: Seminar in United States History
courses.description: Advanced undergraduate topics in U.S. history. Designed for HTS majors, but open to other students with junior or senior standing.

courses.title: Seminar in Sociology
courses.description: Advanced undergraduate topics in sociology. Designed for HTS majors, but open to other students with junior or senior standing.

courses.title: Seminar in European History
courses.description: Advanced undergraduate topics in European history. Designed for HTS majors, but open to other students with junior or senior standing.

courses.title: Seminar in History of Technology
courses.description: Advanced undergraduate topics in the history of technology. Designed for HTS majors, but open to other students with junior or senior standing.

courses.title: Seminar in Health, Medicine, and Society
courses.description: Advanced undergraduate topics in health and medicine.  Designed for HTS majors and HMS minors, but open to other students with junior or senior standing.

courses.title: HTS Internship-Paid
courses.description: Undergraduate internship for which the student is paid and receives audit credit. Juniors and seniors only.

courses.title: HTS Internship-Credit
courses.description: Unpaid undergraduate internship for which the student receives pass/fail credit.  Juniors and seniors only.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research Assistantship
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Topics of interest  not covered in the regular course offering.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Topics of interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

courses.description: Topics of interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Topics of current interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Allows a group of students and a professor to study topics not covered in other courses in the department.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Allows a group of students and a professor to study topics not covered in other courses in the department.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Allows a student and a professor to study topics not included in other courses in the department.

courses.title: Special Problems in History, Technology, and Society
courses.description: Individual studies of topics of current interest in history, technology, and society.

courses.title: Special Problems in History, Technology, and Society
courses.description: Individual studies of topics of current interest in History, Technology, and Society.

courses.title: Special Problems in History, Technology, and Society
courses.description: Individual studies of topics of current interest in History, Technology, and Society.

courses.title: Special Problems in History, Technology, and Society
courses.description: Individual studies of topics of current interest in History, Technology, and Society.

courses.title: Special Problems in History, Technology, and Society
courses.description: Individual studies of topics of current interest in History, Technology, and Society.

courses.title: Proseminar in Social Theory
courses.description: An introduction to key theoretical traditions in modern social theory, including both classical and contemporary works.

courses.title: Proseminar in the History of Technology
courses.description: Identifies major areas of interest in the history of technology and introduces a variety of approaches to the discipline.

courses.title: Historical Methods
courses.description: An introduction to key historical traditions and methodological approaches.

courses.title: Social and Political History of the United States
courses.description: Examines the social experiences of Americans and the political contexts in which they lived.

courses.title: Social and Political History of Europe
courses.description: Classic works and debates in European social history, including transition from feudalism to capitalism, French Revolution, rural history and industrialization, and origins of nationalism.

courses.title: Social and Political History of the Nonwestern World
courses.description: Covers basic empirical and relevant theoretical literature in English on the social and political history of Africa, Asia, and/or Latin America.

courses.title: Business Organizations and Political Economy
courses.description: Examines the historical evolution and contemporary operations of business institutions within the larger context of political economy; emphasis on business, government, and technology.

courses.title: Gender, Science, and Technology
courses.description: Examines the ways in which gendered relations shape scientific and technological institutions, careers, artifacts, knowledge, and culture.

courses.title: Technology and Modern Culture
courses.description: Introduces the complex interplay between technological systems and diffuse systems of consumption, social organization, and culture beyond the act of production.

courses.title: Studies in Science and Engineering
courses.description: Empirical investigation of scientific and engineering practice in historical and contemporary settings.

courses.title: Development, Technology and Science
courses.description: Explores the impact of science and technology on development and modernization.  Credit not allowed for both HTS 6113 and HTS 4011.

courses.title: Topics in the History of Science
courses.description: Explores topics in the history of science in their social and political contexts.

courses.title: Sociology of Science and Technology
courses.description: Explores current debates in the history of the sociology of science and technology.  Credit not allowed for both HTS 6115 and HTS 3082.

courses.title: The Environment in World History
courses.description: Surveys the field of global environmental history with examples taken from biology, geography, sociology and anthropology.

courses.title: Urbanization
courses.description: An intensive introduction to the political, social, and economic forces involved in the process of urbanization.  Credit not allowed for both HTS 6117 and HTS 6105.

courses.title: Science, Technology and the Economy
courses.description: Examines how science and technology are related to economic institutions and processes.  Credit not allowed for both HTS 6118 and HTS 6107.

courses.title: Race and Ethnicity
courses.description: Examines the structural impact of racism and ethnic discrimination on American society, and the controversies over racial and ethnic identity. Credit not allowed for both HTS 6119 and HTS 6108.

courses.title: Inequality, Science and Technology
courses.description: Explores the impacts of science and technology on inequality, as well as how notions of difference have shaped science and technology.  Credit not allowed for both HTS 6120 and HTS 6109.

courses.title: Science, Technology, and National Security
courses.description: Topics in the study of the relationship between national security and the scientific-technological enterprise from diverse perspectives.

courses.title: History of Medicine
courses.description: The impact of disease in history, modern developments in medicine and health focusing on western medicine in a global context.

courses.title: Social and Cultural Studies of Biomedicine
courses.description: Introduces students to the changing social, political, and corporate worlds of the biological sciences, biotechnology, and biomedicine.

courses.title: Science and Technology Beyond Borders
courses.description: Discusses the roles of science and technology as instruments of social control and of social change in development and modernization.  Credit not allowed for both HTS 6124 and HTS 6104.

courses.title: Quantitative Methods in Social Research
courses.description: Introduces statistical reasoning and trains students in methods and tools of quantitative research in the humanities and social sciences.

courses.title: Science, Technology & Soceity: Core Seminar
courses.description: This survey course covers key works in Science, Technology & Society, and guest lectures introduce students to faculty doing STS-related research across the Ivan Allen College.  Credit not allowed for both HTS 6743 and PUBP 6743 or LCC 6743.

courses.title: Research Paper
courses.description: Under the direct supervision of one or more faculty members, graduate students will complete an original research design and execute that study.

courses.title: Foundations of Socio-historical Analysis
courses.description: Introduces key concepts and methods used in the historical analysis of social phenomena.

courses.title: Research and Writing Seminar
courses.description: Introduces methods of sociohistorical research and writing; requires preparation of an original research paper based on primary sources.

courses.title: Comprehensive Exam Preparation
courses.description: Preparation for comprehensive exam in fields of history or sociology.

courses.title: Comparative History of Labor, Industry, Technology, and Society
courses.description: An intensive, team-taught reading seminar covering major themes and classic works in these fields.

courses.title: Teaching Assistantship
courses.description: For graduate students holding a teaching assistantship.

courses.title: Research Assistantship
courses.description: For graduate students holding a research assistantship.
